Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: The Evolution of Great-Ape Gut Microbiomes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nearly every environment on earth contains communities of microbes, including the guts of animals, where microbes are increasingly known to play a major role in nutrition and disease. This project aims to develop a new technique for measuring the abundances of the different types of microbes in the guts of the closest relatives of humans, the great apes. Researchers will combine microscopy and gene amplification and sequencing to quantify the total numbers of the various bacterial species that reside within the guts of chimpanzees, bonobos, and two species of gorillas. Results will provide new insights into how disease, evolutionary history, geography, and diet shape the internal microbial communities of primates.

The broader impacts of this project include the development of a molecular technique that could find wide application in the study of microbes in medicine and biology. The project will provide research training for a doctoral student and two undergraduate students. The doctoral student will mentor the undergraduates and gain teaching experience towards his goal of starting his own lab.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A major limitation of research regarding the bacterial communities residing within humans and other environments is a lack of information about the absolute number of living bacteria within a sample. This limitation arises because commonly employed methods only provide estimates of relative frequencies of bacterial DNA molecules. We developed and applied methods for estimating bacterial density directly from environmental samples. In particular, we estimated bacterial density in human feces using two independent methods, hemocytometer counting and fluorescence automated cell sorting, yielding highly concordant results. This work revealed that bacterial density is relatively stable within individual hosts, providing justification for the use of relative frequencies of bacterial types to estimate fundamental properties of bacterial communities, such as species richness. 

In the second part of the project, we characterized the bacterial communities residing within the gastrointestinal tracts of one of humanity's closest relatives, the orangutan. We found that the orangutan gut microbiome is exceptionally diverse: individual orangutans harbor a greater number of species of bacteria than do individual humans, chimpanzees, bonobos, or gorillas. These results support the hypothesis that humans have lost ancestral bacterial diversity since divergence from chimpanzees. The consequences of this loss of ancestral diversity from the human lineage are not yet fully understood. These results generate new areas for research regarding the relationships that have evolved between apes and their gut bacteria.
